> > > Hello there,

> > > I am =
using the following CPPN model for the substrate: 
> > > 
> > > Inputs: X1,=
 Y1, X2, Y2, BIAS
> > > Outputs: Weight, Node-Bias, Node-Time_Constant
> > =
> 
> > > The time constant range is [0.5 .. 5.0] and the weight/node-
bias =

> > range 
> > > within the substrate in [-8.0 .. 8.0]. 
> > > The weight =
range in the CPPN is unbounded. 
> > > 
> > > The node-specific outputs are=
 computed using (X1, Y1, BIAS) and 
> > the 
> > > others set to 0.
> > > 
=
> > > The activation functions used are plain sigmoid, gaussian, and 
> > s=
ine. 
> > > The CTRNN substrate activates with 0.02 timestep and it is used=
 
> to 
> > > control a 3D humanoid model, simulated in a physical 
environ=
ment 
> > (using 
> > > Open Dynamics Engine http://www.ode.org ). 
> > > 
=
> > > The thing I notice, is the following: 
> > > 
> > > The first network=
s are simple, and so the connective patterns 
> are. 
> > But 
> > > the no=
de biases and time constants are also simple. When I 
watch 
> > an 
> > > =
animaion of the activation changing in the substrate, it looks 
> > like it=
 
> > > exibits a pattern. The simplest I've seen can be described as a 
> =
> mexican 
> > > wave travelling across the hidden nodes. 
> > > As the CPP=
Ns complexify, so do the activity patterns exibited. 
> > When 
> > > using=
 regular NEAT for the problem of keeping the humanoid 
model 
> > > balance=
d, it has moslty erratic behaviour, and the lucky ones 
> > (with 
> > > hi=
gh fitness) usually find a way to trick the system and stay 
in 
> a 
> > >=
 balanced position forever, without moving at all. 
> > > But when HyperNEA=
T is used for this, it looks really 
interesting 
> > and.. 
> > > natural!=
 The model is trying to balance using its arms, and it 
is 
> > > moving.. =
It looks like a drunk guy, but you note the 
difference. 
> > > I've arrang=
ed the nodes in a geometric way.. Let me explain - 
the 
> > left 
> > > an=
d right arm's outputs are separated in the left and right in 
> the 
> > > =
substrate space, and close to each other. So do the legs. The 
> > hidden 
=

included

smal=
ler
